column4: How do I access the "Software channel" as described when I went to install a package "it's better if you install this through the software channel"?
never heard that term, where is it used?
I went to reinstall ubuntu-desktop, I downloaded the package and I got that message.
what do you mean when you say you "downloaded that package"? you went on the web and got the .deb file? that's certainly not the right method
if you want to reinstall ubuntu-desktop, you type "sudo apt-get --reinstall install ubuntu-desktop", or do the equivalent operation in Synaptic

Larger context...I was trying to upgrade to Pidgin...When I did apt-get remove gaim it took ubuntu-desktop with it...so now I need to reinstall that, and the nautilis in order to get back to where I was
nautilus is installed when you install ubuntu-desktop. anyway, just type the command i gave you (you can leave the "--reinstall" out)
So, is it better generally to install things using aptitude, so if you want to remove later it is easier?
not really, as that feature is now present (since Edgy) in all APT frontends, including apt-get
aptitude is still a quite powerful program, though. google "aptitude manual", if you just look at the "search patterns" section, you'll see just how powerful it is

err...? "ls" is the command to list the contents of a directory. zabi asked about his hardware, "lshw" is a command that shows a lot of information about your computer's hardware. it's completely unrelated to "ls"
Are modprobe -l and lshw very different? if so, what's the difference?

atselby: it means that the package was installed automatically (due to being a dependency of some other package) and can be automatically removed by invoking "apt-get autoremove" when it's no longer needed.
the stuff you put in grep
Someone being a little testy about advice they were given. . .
